Questions.QuestionString:
39. If an aircraft has ability to transfer fuel in flight, provision must be made to.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. shut off fuel before structural damage.
B. provide overflow facility to dump fuel.
C. stop engine from using tank during transfer.

Answers: A. an expansion space is not required.
B. the expansion space must be 2% of the tank capacity.

Questions.QuestionString:
42. When an aircraft is put into storage for medium / long periods, the fuel tanks
should. (Level 3)
Answers: A. have some fuel left in to prevent sealant from deteriorating/drying out.

Questions.QuestionString: 43. The purpose of a scavenge system within a fuel system is. (Level 3)
Answers: A. to ensure that all unused fuel is returned to the tanks efficiently.
B. to ensure that all available fuel can be used.

C. to ensure that any water in the fuel is constantly dispersed thus reducing
microbiological contamination.

B. the tank should be filled with the minimum fuel possible.
C. the filler cap should be left open.

63. Which are the main characteristics of Jet A1?
Answers: A. High flash point 20° C, low freezing -60° C.
B. High flash point 10° C, low freezing -40° C.
C. High flash point 38° C, low freezing -47° C.

Questions.QuestionString: 64. What is an other very important characteristic of fuel?
65. Which condition does jet fuel to vaporize?
66. What is freezing point?

B. Is the temperature at which elements of the fuel start to crystallize

C. Is the temperature at which elements of the fuel start to change the
characteristics

Questions.QuestionString:
67. What are the problems if water accumulation is in the fuel tanks?
1. encourages ice build up if fuel cools down below 0°C.
2. supports corrosion of components in fuel system.
3. large amounts of water in fuel can cause engine power fluctuations or flame
outs.
4. cause erratic fuel quantity indicating.
5. microbial growth in the tanks.
Answers:
A. 1. encourages ice build up if fuel cools down below 0°C.
2. supports corrosion of components in fuel system.
3. large amounts of water in fuel can cause engine power fluctuations or flame outs.
4. cause erratic fuel quantity indicating.
5. microbial growth in the tanks.

B. 1. encourages ice build up if fuel cools down below 0°C.
2. supports corrosion of components in fuel system.
3. large amounts of water in fuel can cause engine power fluctuations or flame outs.

C. 1. encourages ice build up if fuel cools down below 0°C.
2. supports corrosion of components in fuel system.
indicating.
5. microbial growth in the tanks.

Questions.QuestionString: 68. How can you check the water inside fuel when do refueling?
Answers: B. Using a syringe test cartridge and chemically treated filter

Questions.QuestionString:
69. What does the main fuel storage system consists of?
1. Fuel tanks.
2. Tank drain system.
3. Tank vent system.

A. 1. Fuel tanks.
2. Tank drain system.

B. 1. Fuel tanks.
3. Tank vent system.

C. 1. Fuel tanks.
2. Tank drain system.
3. Tank vent system.

Questions.QuestionString: 70. Normally, Where is the additional tanks located in the civil aircraft?

Questions.QuestionString: 71. What is the most common types of main fuel tank on modern jet aircraft?

Questions.QuestionString: 72. How does seal 2 plates join in fuel tank?
